This week marked the beginning of Lent, and I want to share my first Lenten Season Sunday Reflection with you.  Today is the 55th anniversary of Bloody Sunday ‚Äî a pivotal day in the Civil Rights Movement. The activists who marched on this day were seeking equal voting rights ‚Äî something we are still struggling to win today. Here in our state of Georgia, we still see voter suppression, perpetuated by our own Governor.  5 and a half decades after the historical march in Selma, Black people are still fighting for equal rights. As I reflect on the gruesome acts of that day in 1965, I feel inspired by the great courage those marchers had, how they stood up for injustice and helped galvanize Congress to pass the Voting Rights Act.  Georgia‚Äôs recent voter suppression tactics have proved that we need to do more to ensure all Georgians have equal opportunity ‚Äî  and I hope you'll join me in this fight.

Kicking off Women's History Month celebrating the Black women who led and served as the backbone of the U.S. Labor movement. As a staunch supporter of worker's rights, I commend these women for their tireless work.

Today is #AshWednesday, the first day of Lent for people in the Christian faith tradition. Between Ash Wednesday and the Easter holiday, many Christians will participate in a 40 day "fast" ‚Äî from sugar, or caffeine, for example ‚Äî to deepen their faith and focus on what it means to be a servant of God. Lenten fasting, meant to emulate Jesus' forty day fast in the desert, helps us remember that we have a purpose beyond our own interests. As Lent begins today, I am mindful that our collective purpose includes loving our neighbors and caring for the 'least of these' in our world: the poor, the sick, the hungry, the widowed, the orphan, the wrongly convicted, the asylum seeker, the refugee ‚Äî and all who are oppressed.  This Lenten season, I'm honored that every day I get to meet Georgians ‚Äî from all faiths and backgrounds ‚Äî who are fighting against rising hate, division, and injustice.  I will be posting a weekly reflection every Sunday during Lent, focusing on how we can best serve the people of Georgia. Please join me, no matter how or if you pray, on this journey as we contemplate the call to accountability and justice, which require sacrificing our comfort and privilege so that we can truly love our neighbors.

Finally. Justice for the 4,000 victims, their families, and communities has been long overdue. We must reckon with our racist history to make progress. That starts with passing today's Emmett Till Anti-Lynching Act. But we can't stop there, we have to work every day to dismantle white supremacy.

We met during the 2018 campaign, becoming fast friends over shared stories as moms of strong young daughters and the shared hope that our faith communities could be a part of making the world a better, more just place for future generations. Today, Rabbi Rachael spoke eloquently on the importance of loving our neighbors ‚Äî no matter their beliefs. She spoke from Leviticus (19:18,34), and from the heart. I‚Äôm so grateful I was there to hear her wise words and to stand in solidarity with our Jewish community in Georgia.

Today‚Äôs impeachment vote is a gravely serious moment for our country. The House of Representatives, in accordance with its constitutional duties, had no choice but to condemn the President for his brazen abuse of power and betrayal of his sworn oath. The President has repeatedly flaunted the fact that he put his personal political agenda ahead of his obligations to his country and office, and in the process, threatened American national security and the security of a European ally. Today is not cause for celebration. It is a sober lesson that corruption cannot and will not be tolerated in the United States. But impeachment is not the result of a single action taken by the President. This offense represents only the latest in a troubling and escalating surge of violations that were enabled by unchecked power. It is my hope that Senators in both parties will consider the evidence put forward in the House and take seriously their duties to represent the people who sent them to Washington. Georgians deserve elected leaders with unwavering commitment to our Constitution, democratic institutions, and the sacred duties to uphold our national interests that we entrust to our public servants. Today‚Äôs vote sounds a national alarm that the very fabric of our republic is at risk. For Georgia‚Äôs sake, and the sake of our country, I hope Senator David Perdue heard it.

‚Ä™‚ÄúBlack voters were 20% more likely to miss elections because of long distances.‚Äù‚Ä¨  ‚ÄúPrecinct closures and longer distances likely prevented an estimated 54,000 to 85,000 voters from casting ballots on Election Day last year, according to the AJC‚Äôs findings.‚Äù This is such an important issue. Please take a few minutes to read this stunning The Atlanta Journal-Constitution piece by Mark Niesse on the impact of precinct closures in GA with respect to minority voter turnout in the 2018 election.  As background: ‚Ä™The 2013 Supreme Court decision in Shelby County v. Holder struck down Section 4(b) of the Voting Rights Act, a formula determining which states with a history of voting discrimination (including GA) required ‚Äúpre-clearance‚Äù of state/local voting procedures changes to prevent harm to minority voters. ‚Ä™The effects in Georgia have been chilling. ‚Ä™The AJC reported that from 2012 to 2018 ‚Äúcounty election officials shut down 8% of Georgia‚Äôs polling places and relocated nearly 40% of the state‚Äôs precincts.‚Äù‚Ä¨ ‚Ä™Most of these changes happened after the 2013 Shelby decision. ‚Ä™These changes disproportionately impacted minority voters in Georgia.‚Ä¨ From the article: ‚Ä™‚ÄúBlack voters were 20% more likely to miss elections because of long distances.‚Ä¨‚Äù ‚Ä™‚ÄúAbout 30% of black voters must now travel across half of their precinct to reach their poll compared to less than 20% of white voters.‚Äù ‚Ä™The AJC found that before the Shelby ruling, ‚Äúvoters of all races were barely affected by their distance to the polls, accounting for a 0.2% and 0.4% reduction in turnout‚Äù. ‚Ä¨ Between 2012 and 2018, that numbered quadrupled.  ‚Ä™In fact, the AJC‚Äôs independent statistical analysis found that ‚ÄúTurnout by black voters would have been between 1.3% and 2.1% higher on Election Day in 2018 if they all lived near their polling places.‚Äù This is one of the reasons voting rights and election security are core platforms of my US Senate campaign.  ‚Ä™ The Shelby decision struck down Section 4(b) of the Voting Rights Act, which outlined the FORMULA used to determine the states & local jurisdictions that would be subject to the Voting Rights Act‚Äôs pre-clearance requirements.  However, Section 5 ‚Äî the section of the Voting Rights Act that provides for federal oversight of covered jurisdictions ‚Äî still stands.‚Ä¨ ‚Ä™The numbers in Georgia show that it‚Äôs time to restore the full protections for minority voters that were provided in the Voting Rights Act.  The good news is that Democratic leaders in the US House of Representatives already are working to restore minority voter protections that were gutted by the Shelby v. Holder decision.  Now, we need a Democratic Senate that will take decisive action to strengthen voting rights & election security, so that all Americans have equal access to vote!  As a US Senator, I will make protecting the security of American elections a priority. And I will work tirelessly to protect your right ‚Äî the rights of every eligible voter ‚Äî to vote. https://t.co/PPJLF1ZrmU?amp=1

Governor* Kemp‚Äôs appointment of Republican mega-donor Kelly Loeffler to the US Senate (over Donald Trump‚Äôs preferred nominee) shows that even the President‚Äôs closest allies see him as a liability.  Unfortunately for the Georgia GOP, voters aren't looking for more wealthy special interest power in Washington. They want public servants who will defend a woman's right to make her own health care decisions, my children's right to learn and play in environments safe from active shooters, and policies that provide economic security and opportunities for working families.  Come November 2020, I'm confident that Georgia voters will replace Kelly Loeffler with a Senator who shares our values and truly represents the people.

As a mother, I find this absolutely heartbreaking - and unacceptable. Taking children away from parents who came to our country seeking asylum and refuge ‚Äî from violence, poverty and abuse ‚Äî is tantamount to the abduction and trafficking of migrant children. Families belong together.  https://thehill.com/policy/international/americas/410653-ap-migrant-children-may-be-adopted-after-parents-are-deported

"According to those on strike, the strong growth is precisely the point. Autoworkers, teachers and other workers accepted austerity when the economy was in a free fall, expecting to share in the gains once the recovery took hold." This is just it - too many people are being left out and shut out of the opportunities for economic growth, and they're struggling to make ends meet while the gap grows wider. We need to build an economy that works for everyone.

Thank you Democratic Party of Georgia for inviting me to say a few words about protecting women‚Äôs rights to their own bodies and workers‚Äô rights to collectively bargain. If we keep this momentum going into 2020 there is no doubt that Democrats will win the US Senate.

As the mother of two young girls, I am disappointed and concerned by the announcement of the Pickens County School Board to suspend their decision allowing transgender students to use restrooms that align with their gender identity; such actions undermine the health, safety, and well-being of all of their students. Parents and educators must stand together in refusing to cower to threats of any kind, and commit to protecting the safety, dignity, and rights of all of our children, including trans students, who are a loved and valued part of our community.

As a business owner and a Christian, I am appalled that any business would seek to discriminate against anyone for who they are or who they love. No one should face the fear of discrimination -- not in their place of worship, not in their community, and certainly not at work. At my business, I‚Äôve worked to ensure we have a workplace in which our employees can live and work free to be who they are. We‚Äôve enacted policies to support those values, including paid leave for LGBTQ employees welcoming new children into their families. That‚Äôs how you run an inclusive and supportive business.   The highest court in the United States must decide whether it stands with the LGBTQ+ community and for workers' rights, or if we regress into intolerance. It is time to show our true colors -- the whole spectrum.

It has been 43 years since the Hyde Amendment passed, which largely prohibits Medicaid and Medicare recipients from using their health insurance to access abortion care. This legislation is not only devastating to men and women who need medical attention, it is also blatantly racist in its targeting of those who are least likely to have access to care - women of color - and those who often need it the most. More than a million Georgians are covered by Medicaid - men and women who deserve the same access to reproductive health care and abortion services the rest of us have.  It is long past time to repeal the Hyde Amendment and end this unlawful discrimination #BeBoldEndHyde
Shanah Tovah to all who are celebrating #RoshHashanah! May your new year be sweet, beautiful and peaceful.

On July 25th, President Trump spoke to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Related to President Trump‚Äôs actions and behavior on that call, on August 12, an unnamed intelligence officer filed a whistleblower complaint with Michael Atkinson, the Intelligence Community Inspector General. The IC IG found the complaint credible and deemed the matter of ‚Äúurgent concern.‚Äù The contents of the whistleblower‚Äôs complaint have not yet been made public, nor have they been shared with the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence ‚Äî the first time a credible whistleblower complaint has ever been withheld from the Committee, according to its Chairman Rep. Adam Schiff. Publications including The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, and The Washington Post, however, are reporting that during their call President Trump repeatedly asked President Zelensky to work with President Trump‚Äôs personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son. Despite initial denials, President Trump has now admitted he did discuss the former Vice President while speaking with President Zelensky. Further, President Trump has publicly acknowledged that he took actions to delay nearly $400 million in military aid to Ukraine ‚Äî and that he did so mere days before his July 25th call with President Zelensky. Military aid, appropriated by Congress from taxpayer money, is frequently used to bolster America‚Äôs alliances, protect national security interests, and promote global stability. If the whistleblower‚Äôs reported allegations are true, they are extremely serious. It is unlawful and immoral for the President of the United States to dangle foreign aid as a political bribe in exchange for investigating his political opponents. Jeopardizing American national security interests and using American influence for the personal benefit of the President is more than unacceptable ‚Äî it is the definition of corruption. The Inspector General should immediately release the full scope of the ‚Äòcredible and urgent‚Äô whistleblower complaint as well as all corroborating evidence.  Further, Senator David Perdue should publicly state whether he supports a full investigation of the whistleblower complaint, so that members of Congress can fulfill their Constitutional oversight and investigation duties. The Trump administration‚Äôs chronic abuse of power continues to test the limits of our democracy. It‚Äôs time for Congress to act. It‚Äôs time to begin impeachment proceedings. Our founding fathers established a system of checks and balances to hold power accountable: And that‚Äôs exactly what needs to happen. It‚Äôs the job Congress was elected to do, frankly it‚Äôs the job that Senator Perdue was elected to do, no matter the party affiliation. The American people deserve accountability.  As such, I support the House of Representatives' move to begin formal impeachment proceedings.
Fact.

Climate change is one of the greatest threats facing our world today. We've seen the effects firsthand here in Georgia, including from Hurricane Michael which swept through last year, leaving destruction and death in its wake. I want my daughters to inherit an earth that is beautiful and healthy and sustainable, which is one of many reasons I stand with all those calling for bold, large-scale action.

My girls Ava and Sofia are a decade out from their college careers, but this conversation cannot wait. We need to think about the world we are creating for our children's future.

I am a strong believer in transforming our economy to tackle the challenges of man-made climate change. I'm also a strong believer in protecting the access to clean water for our most vulnerable communities and our future generations. We need to protect access to clean water as the human right that it is.  In the Senate, I won't back down against corrupt Republicans who want to recklessly pollute or plunder our environment.

We cannot allow Trump and his enablers to have any more time at the steering wheel driving our country off a cliff.  "The average tariff on Chinese imports has risen from 3.1% before Trump got tariff-happy, to 21.2% now, according to Chad Bown of the Petersen Institute for International Economics." These tariffs are passed on to consumers from American importers. And when they can't pass those ever ratcheting price increases down to us, they absorb the cost by firing workers or lowering their standards. We cannot allow this to go on any longer. We need an economy that works for all Americans.

As a business executive and a mother, I fully support expanding background checks and ensuring our families can be safe in their schools, their places of worship, their homes, and their communities. Doing nothing is simply unacceptable.

Thank you HILL TV for (another) good discussion on the latest in #Georgia politics! #gapol https://thehill.com/hilltv/rising/444544-ex-georgia-candidate-sarah-riggs-amico-discusses-states-new-abortion-law

I‚Äôm proud to announce my endorsement of Senator Senator Ron Wyden‚Äôs election security bill, the PAVE Act. This bill would ensure secure & accurate federal elections by requiring paper ballots, which would be subject to the voter‚Äôs verification before counting. https://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/wyden-and-bicameral-coalition-introduce-bill-to-require-states-to-secure-elections-  The PAVE Act would prohibit the use of paperless machines, like those used in the 2018 elections here in #Georgia, where election security experts found deeply flawed vote counts that could have had a dramatic impact on the outcome of our election. In my race for Lt. Governor, we saw a suspiciously large drop off of almost 160,000 votes, although those voters did cast ballots for remaining down ballot races. As has been reported by multiple data security experts & news outlets, this is highly unusual (see this AJC piece: https://ajc.com/blog/politics/time-solve-the-mystery-the-100-000-missing-votes/nEYXrcGW8et8esyVL6W4QM/) Drop off among absentee voters (#HandMarkedPaperBallots) was normal in the 2018 #Georgia Lt. Governor‚Äôs race.  In other words, the suspiciously high voter drop off occurred ONLY on ballots cast via Georgia‚Äôs touchscreen, DRE voting machines, which have been deemed vulnerable by cyber security experts.  Data scientists determined 2018 voter drop off from Gov to Lt Gov was highly unusual vs. recent Georgia elections. Additionally suspicious: drop off was disproportionately high in Democratic-leaning counties & African-American precincts. (See this article from The Root: https://www.theroot.com/exclusive-thousands-of-black-votes-in-georgia-disappea-1832472558?utm_source=share&utm_medium=ios_app) Coincidence? What we do know is that, at a minimum, part of the blame falls on the notoriously faulty DRE voting machines and a flawed voting system. Experts and voters agree ‚Äî these machines have got to go.  As I‚Äôve said countless times, this isn‚Äôt just about the outcome of one election ‚Äî it‚Äôs about the integrity of ALL our elections. It‚Äôs about the trust and faith the American people should have that their fundamental right to vote is being protected. The portions of the Mueller Report that have been made available to the public shed additional light on this issue ‚Äî exposing the fact that in 2016, voting machines infrastructure in multiple states was hacked by foreign operatives with the intent of manipulating our elections. We can conclude that this is only the beginning, and that Russian cyberattacks on our #2020Elections are not only possible, but perhaps likely, if we do not take swift and dramatic action to counter their efforts and secure our votes.  Georgia Tech Professors Wenke Lee and Richard DeMillo have also endorsed the PAVE Act, even as their calls for #HandMarkedPaperBallots in Georgia have been willfully ignored by Governor Brian Kemp‚Äôs administration.  Brian Kemp (whose time as Secretary of State was rife w/accusations of voter suppression) denies the flaws of our voting systems. His Deputy Chief of Staff is a former lobbyist for ES&S, a voting machine company currently vying for a $150 million contract with the state of Georgia. (Press coverage: https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/firm-close-ties-georgia-stir-concerns-about-voting-system-purchase/HVK4wcNsEAKO0Xa0ptLLKM/) A recent expos√© by The New Yorker highlights the corrupt nature of the ties between voting machine lobbyists and political operatives, like Brian Kemp‚Äôs employees. You can read the expos√© here: https://www.newyorker.com/tech/annals-of-technology/how-voting-machine-lobbyists-undermine-the-democratic-process The bottom line: We cannot trust our fundamental rights ‚Äî our very democracy ‚Äî to hackable, insecure, inaccurate voting machines whose makers are in bed with politicians for the sake of huge contracts that put profits (and political power) over people.  Congress must take action to ensure the security of our votes in advance of the #2020Elections. The PAVE Act is the solution; it will correct the vast deficiencies of flawed voting machines, which leave us vulnerable to foreign interference such as we witnessed in 2016.  American voters deserve to have voter-verified paper ballots, so they can have confidence that their votes will be counted safely, securely and accurately. Thats the America we deserve, and that‚Äôs the America Sen. Ron Wyden‚Äôs PAVE Act is going to ensure.  Having met with Senator Wyden about his efforts to secure our elections, and having discussed the ways the PAVE Act can do just that, I am proud to support it.

#TBT: In honor of #NursesAppreciationWeek, I‚Äôm sharing some photos of my beautiful mom as a neonatal #nurse, caring for some of the most vulnerable babies in NICU. Mom‚Äôs nursing experience helped shape my belief that every American has a right to affordable #healthcare. She also taught me that maternal health is critical to healthy families and children. In #Georgia, 79 of our 159 counties do not have an OB/GYN. Our state has the highest maternal mortality in America - a crisis that disproportionately affects African American women.  As the daughter of a former NICU nurse, I know that women, children and all Georgia families deserve better.
As #Ramadan  begins this evening, I‚Äôd like to wish our Muslim communities in Georgia ‚Äî and around the world ‚Äî #RamadanMubarak

The political dysfunction paralyzing Washington is actively harming Georgia workers and families, and we can‚Äôt allow it to go unchallenged. We deserve bold, inclusive policies that lift up and engage all communities across Georgia.  In the coming weeks, I‚Äôm going to be listening to Georgians from around the state to determine if I‚Äôm the candidate to drive that vision forward in Georgia‚Äôs 2020 election for the US Senate. I am truly grateful for the support and encouragement I have received as Andrea, the girls, and I, consider this remarkable opportunity to serve our state.  Finally, I want to thank Stacey Abrams for her leadership in the 2018 election. It was an honor to run alongside her last year as Stacey inspired voters across Georgia to turn out in record numbers. Our state needs that kind of bold leadership and I look forward to seeing the Democratic Party of Georgia build on that momentum in 2020.  The work Stacey has done - and is still doing at Fair Fight Action - will strengthen our state, our nation and our democracy for future generations. I am grateful for her work, her commitment to public service, and her friendship. #gapol https://www.ajc.com/blog/politics/the-jolt-with-stacey-abrams-out-democratic-race-for-senate-begins/wvj79aJZpMmmBBAhomdZeK/
Hope to see some folks on Monday! #gapol

Sharing this thread on maternal mortality - which is shamefully high across the country (worst of the developed world) and in Georgia (which ranks 50/50 states in the metric üò¢). This crisis exposes vast racial inequity in our healthcare system: the risk of pregnancy-related death is 3-4 times higher for black women. If you have a story about Georgia‚Äôs maternal health crisis, please share it below or send me a message. These stories deserve to be heard.  During our campaign last year, I spoke often about the lack of access to pre-/post-natal care for women in the 79 counties without an OB/GYN and women who lack insurance (the problem so disturbed me that we included Georgia‚Äôs maternal health crisis in our general election commercial).  It‚Äôs critical that we engage on this issue and turn up the pressure for our state to cure what has become a crisis in maternal health. Our leader must take action; it‚Äôs literally a matter of life and death. https://twitter.com/sarahriggsamico/status/1122110380455682050?s=21

For our family, Easter services & time with extended family today took on a new poignancy after the horrific events in Sri Lanka. We join people around the world in praying for the people of Sri Lanka, the victims of these vicious attacks, and their loved ones. The Easter story is a message of hope & light in some of the world‚Äôs darkest moments; it is a promise of redemption & restoration in times when they seem more elusive than ever. Tonight, I am particularly grateful for the blessed assurance of Easter. To all who celebrated, I hope Easter brought you joy. May the Easter story renew your commitment to the Gospel of peace and to Christ‚Äôs commandment that we love one another as He loved us (John 13:34-35). The world needs that kind of humble, selfless love - as much now as it ever has.

My heart aches. Today, on Easter, we see houses of worship are yet again targets of terror. No one should fear for their life in the place where they worship their Creator - whether that‚Äôs churches in Sri Lanka, a synagogue in Pennsylvania, mosques in New Zealand, or a Sikh temple in Wisconsin.  The high cost of hate is too often paid by the innocent. People of good conscience from all walks of life must be unequivocal - and vocal - in condemning these vicious attacks.  I am praying for the people of Sri Lanka, the victims, and all who mourn them. May God‚Äôs peace that surpasses all understanding comfort them.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/coordinated-explosions-rock-three-churches-and-two-hotels-in-sri-lanka-on-easter-sunday/2019/04/21/a09002a0-63f6-11e9-9ff2-abc984dc9eec_story.html?utm_term=.a89bd19f23ac&tid=sm_fb
Wishing all who celebrate a #HappyPassover! May this time focused on faith & family be a blessing to you. #ChagSameach #Passover #Pesach
